FACADE.deftext:
the front (of a building); a false appearance

Note the pronunciation. The c is soft.

The FACADE of a building is its front, the part which faces the street and which most people see.

“The bomb damaged the FACADE of the hotel, but the people inside were unharmed.”

Sometimes, to make a small building appear to be bigger than it actually is, the FACADE is extended above the building’s top floor. Such a FACADE is called a false front.

“The FACADE of the building is two stories high, but the building has only one floor.”

From this meaning FACADE has come to be used for any outward appearance, especially one which is false or misleading.

“She looked calm, but this was just a FACADE; she was really very angry.”

“Their apparent wealth was all a FACADE; in fact, they could barely afford the clothes they wore.”

Usage: FACADE is also sometimes spelled façade.

ADULTERATE.deftext:
to make impure, corrupt, pollute

ADULTERATE has nothing to do with the word adult. To ADULTERATE something is to make it less pure, usually by adding a substance that is of poorer quality. The word is used especially about foods and drugs.

“He claimed the hamburger had been ADULTERATED by the addition of harmful chemicals.”

The word is also sometimes used in a general sense.

“Her happiness was ADULTERATED by the continuing suspicion that it was all about to end.”

The word UNADULTERATED means pure or sheer.

“Everything he says is UNADULTERATED nonsense"--that is, it is complete and total nonsense.

Other forms of the word: ADULTERATION, n. UNADULTERATED, adj.

CLEAVE.deftext:
to split, tear, cut apart

To CLEAVE something is to split it apart, especially with a cutting blow--for example, from an ax.

“He could CLEAVE the log with one mighty swing of his ax.”

“The force of the explosion CLEAVED the boulder in two.”

CLEAVE can also he used about the thing being cut.

“This kind of wood CLEAVES easily.”

In a slightly different sense, the word can also mean “to make way for, by (or as if by) cutting.”

“They CLEAVED a path through the jungle.”

A CLEAVER is a heavy instrument used by butchers to cut up animals.

Other forms of the word: CLEAVER, n.

Usage: CLEAVE is a rather formal word, used more in print than in speech. The past tense of CLEAVE can be CLEAVED, CLOVE, or CLEFT. Interestingly, CLEAVE has a second meaning that is almost the opposite of the meaning given above; it means “to cling to or be firmly attached to,” as in “The wet uniforms cleaved to their bodies.”

ENUMERATE.deftext:
to count, list, name one by one

ENUMERATE comes from the same Latin source as number, numeral, numerous, and other words having to do with numbers and counting. ENUMERATE can mean simply to count, but it usually has the sense of “counting off” or listing items one after another.

“He began to ENUMERATE the reasons why we shouldn’t go.”

“We ENUMERATED the qualities we thought the new employee should have.”

In most cases it is better to use the simpler words count and list, unless the sense is specifically to count off one after another.

Other forms of the word: ENUMERATION, n.

AFFIX.deftext:
to attach, fasten, stick firmly in place

To AFFIX something is to attach it to something else.

“You must AFFIX a stamp to that letter or else the post office won’t deliver it.”

The AFFIXING doesn’t have to be a physical act.

“The teacher AFFIXED a severe penalty to cheating on the test.”

“He AFFIXED great importance to the professor’s remarks.”

AFFIX is often used about adding your signature to something.

“He had to AFFIX his signature to the bottom of the document to make it legal.”

AFFIX comes from the same source as the word fix. AFFIX has nothing to do with fix in the sense of repair. Fix, though, can mean “to put firmly in place” as in the phrase “to fix in your memory.” The two words in this sense have close to the same meaning.

PRECIPICE.deftext:
a steep cliff

A PRECIPICE is a very steep cliff, one that has almost a vertical face to it.

“Everyone was afraid to go very near the edge of the PRECIPICE.”

“The mountain climbers decided it would be almost impossible to reach the top of the PRECIPICE.”

Sometimes PRECIPICE is used in a general sense for the brink of any kind of disaster.

“The nation now stands on the PRECIPICE of a severe economic depression.”

In the Pretest, many people choose valley as the meaning of PRECIPICE. A PRECIPICE is a cliff which might lead down into a valley, but it is not the valley itself.

AGAPE.deftext:
wide open, gaping; in a state of wonder.

AGAPE is related to the words gap and gape. The word means wide open. It is usually used about a person’s mouth, which might be open because of wonder, surprise, a yawn, or the like.

“His mouth was AGAPE when he saw who had walked in the door.”

“The crowd was AGAPE at the astounding feats of the acrobats.”

Many people choose horrified as the synonym for AGAPE. A person’s mouth may be AGAPE because of horror, but the word means wide open, not horrified.

Usage: AGAPE always comes after the noun it modifies.

SUBMISSIVE.deftext:
tame, yielding, compliant, docile

SUBMISSIVE is an adjective from SUBMIT. One meaning of SUBMIT is “to yield to someone else’s authority, to surrender.”

“When the police arrived, the burglar submitted without a struggle.”

Someone who is SUBMISSIVE is inclined to SUBMIT, to yield to power or authority.

“They were very SUBMISSIVE children. They would obey anyone who gave them an order.”

“Why are you so SUBMISSIVE? You shouldn’t do everything he tells you to do.”

Other forms of the word: SUBMIT, v. SUBMISSION, n.

ANTAGONISM.deftext:
hostility, opposition, enmity

ANTAGONISM is active opposition, between people or groups, for example, who are unfriendly or in conflict. The word usually suggests a basic dislike which can easily be stirred up into actual fighting.

“The natives felt an ANTAGONISM toward the tourists who swarmed into their town every summer.”

“Jim’s mother tried to end the ANTAGONISM between his brother and him.”

Many people pick suffering as the meaning of ANTAGONISM, probably because they see the word agony in ANTAGONISM. Actually, both words come from a Greek word meaning struggle, but they have developed very different meanings.

Other forms of the word: ANTAGONIST, n. ANTAGONISTIC, adj. ANTAGONIZE, v.

APPENDAGE.deftext:
an attachment, accessory, addition

The pend part of APPENDAGE comes from the Latin word for hang, also the source of English words like pendant and pendulum. An APPENDAGE is something that is attached or added on to something else so that it is part of it. In biology, arms, legs, tails, and fins are appendages. In general use, however, the word usually suggests that this added-on part is not very important or essential.

“The shed was merely a small APPENDAGE of the large house.”

“The fancy knobs and dials on the machine were useless APPENDAGES; they were just there to make it look impressive.”

To APPEND something is to add or attach it to something else.

“A bibliography was APPENDED to the book before they published the second edition.”

DOMICILE.deftext:
a home, dwelling place, residence

A DOMICILE is a home or dwelling place. The word is especially used to mean “a person’s legal residence"--that is, where he can be considered to live for voting or tax purposes.

“The judge ruled that her legal DOMICILE was in New York State.”

“He decided to establish his DOMICILE in Cleveland"--in other words, he decided to live there.

DOMICILE is also a verb. To DOMICILE is to reside or dwell.

“They DOMICILED in the south of the country during the winter months.”

GUFFAW.deftext:
a noisy burst of laughter

A GUFFAW is a loud, coarse laugh. Originally the word was probably just an imitation of the sound of this kind of laugh.

“The comedian’s act certainly didn’t produce any GUFFAWS in the audience; all we could hear were a few scattered giggles.”

GUFFAW can also be used as a verb.

“The audience GUFFAWED when the villain slipped on a banana peel.”

The most commonly chosen wrong answer on the Pretest is bitter cry, which is opposite in meaning to GUFFAW.

STRATA.deftext:
layers, levels

STRATA is the plural of STRATUM. A STRATUM is an even layer of something. STRATA are several of these layers, one on top of the other. The word is most often used about layers of rocks, but it is also used about other things like social classes.

“Geologists can study the history of the Earth by examining the STRATA of rock formations.”

“Various STRATA of society were represented on the committee.”

BUFFOON.deftext:
a clown, jester

A BUFFOON is a clown, someone who says or does foolish things to entertain people.

“The BUFFOON stood on his head and barked like a dog to amuse the king.”

In general, BUFFOON is an insulting term for any extremely stupid or foolish person.

“He called his opponent a BUFFOON and said he was too stupid to be president.”

BUFFOONERY is clown-like behavior.

“Stop all this BUFFOONERY and act your age.”

The most commonly chosen wrong answer is monkey, probably because of confusion with baboon, which is a kind of monkey.

Other forms of the word: BUFFOONERY, n.

ADVOCATE.deftext:
to recommend, support

To ADVOCATE something is to speak or write publicly in favor of it.

“She ADVOCATES a shorter school day and longer vacations for students.”

“Everyone at the meeting seemed to ADVOCATE a different way of solving the problem.”

“No one on the committee ADVOCATED doing away with taxes entirely.”

ADVOCATE is also a noun. An ADVOCATE is someone who defends or pleads for a cause or a person.

“The plan’s strongest ADVOCATES are the ones who will gain the most from it.”

Other forms of the word: ADVOCACY, n.

questions.prompt: Is the FACADE of a building on the outside?
Is food better after it has been ADULTERATED?
Can an ax CLEAVE a piece of wood?
If you ENUMERATE the difficulties of a plan, do you cause more of them?
Could glue be used to AFFIX a poster to a wall?
Is it dangerous to be on the edge of a PRECIPICE?
Would a person's mouth be AGAPE while he is yawning?
Would a SUBMISSIVE person be easy to get along with?
Do close friends feel a strong ANTAGONISM toward each other?
If you permanently moved to another state, could you keep the same DOMICILE?
Would people GUFFAW at a funeral?
Do STRATA lie beside one another?
Are BUFFOONS supposed to be funny?
Would a salesman ADVOCATE buying his product?
His FACADE of indifference disguised his concern.
That television show is UNADULTERATED trash; it's the worst program I've ever seen.
She CLEAVED the windows with a bucket of water and a sponge.
She quickly ENUMERATED the advantages her idea had over all the rest.
John would have to AFFIX the car whenever it broke down.
The plane was forced to land in a deep PRECIPICE.
The boys stood AGAPE when they saw the ghost suddenly appear.
Some teachers are too SUBMISSIVE; they won't let you get away with anything.
He lay on the ground in ANTAGONISM after he had been wounded.
Jim wanted to be an important part of the team, but the coach made him feel as if he were just an APPENDAGE.
He worked in Los Angeles, but his DOMICILE was outside the city.
His joke brought a loud GUFFAW from everyone.
The highest STRATUM of their society sets the fashion for the other classes.
He called us a bunch of BUFFOONS for acting so silly during the class.
The senator was a strong ADVOCATE of the Equal Rights Amendment.
